headline.main: For Alzheimer’s Patients, Focusing on Comfort

abstract: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
snippet: A Phoenix nursing home has found that unlimited chocolate, and other comforts, go a long way in reducing patients’ distress.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Margaret Nance was, to put it mildly, a difficult case. Agitated, combative, often reluctant to eat, she would hit staff members and fellow residents at nursing homes, several of which kicked her out. But when Beatitudes nursing home agreed to an urgent plea to accept her, all that changed.

abstract: Since there is no treatment, doctors wonder if they should tell people, years earlier, that they have the disease, or a good chance of getting it.
snippet: Since there is no treatment, doctors wonder if they should tell people, years earlier, that they have the disease, or a good chance of getting it.
lead_paragraph: Marjie Popkin thought she had chemo brain, that fuzzy-headed forgetful state that she figured was a result of her treatment for ovarian cancer. She was not thinking clearly — having trouble with numbers, forgetting things she had just heard.

lead_paragraph: SEONGNAM, South Korea  They were stooped, hobbled, disoriented, fumbling around the house. They got confused in the bathtub and struggled up stairs that seemed to swim before them.

abstract: Researchers are trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate. If drugs can be given sooner, they say, treatment might be more successful.

lead_paragraph: Much of the research on Alzheimer’s next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

abstract: More medical research is needed to defeat Alzheimer’s disease before it’s too late to help the baby boom generation.
snippet: More medical research is needed to defeat Alzheimer’s disease before it’s too late to help the baby boom generation.
lead_paragraph: OUR government is ignoring what is likely to become the single greatest threat to the health of Americans: Alzheimer’s disease, an illness that is 100 percent incurable and 100 percent fatal. It attacks rich and poor, white-collar and blue, and women and men, without regard to party. A degenerative disease, it steadily robs its victims of memory, judgment and dignity, leaves them unable to care for themselves and destroys their brain and their identity — often depleting their caregivers and families both emotionally and financially.

abstract: An early sign of dementia is an inability to understand money, leaving financial advisers and lawyers in a bind.
snippet: An early sign of dementia is an inability to understand money, leaving financial advisers and lawyers in a bind.
lead_paragraph: Renee Packel used to have a typical suburban life. Her husband, Arthur, was a lawyer and also sold insurance. They lived in a town house just outside Philadelphia, and Mrs. Packel took care of their home and family.

abstract: This week’s Your Money column discusses how to take on the role of financial guardian for people with Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia.

lead_paragraph: This week’s Your Money column discusses ways to help people with Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia manage their money.
headline.main: Planning for an Aging Parent’s Financial Needs

abstract: The home of an elderly relative of Carl P. Paladino became owned, in turn, by his son, himself, a family trust and a woman who became his mistress.
snippet: The home of an elderly relative of Carl P. Paladino became owned, in turn, by his son, himself, a family trust and a woman who became his mistress.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, when Alzheimer’s disease had begun stealing the faculties of his Aunt Anna, the widow of his beloved Uncle Pasquale, Carl P. Paladino was appointed to safeguard her affairs. Mr. Paladino had significant credentials to serve as his aunt’s financial guardian: he was an established real estate developer and lawyer, someone who would become rich enough to bankroll his own campaign for governor.

abstract: Men develop mild cognitive impairment, often a precursor to Alzheimer’s disease, earlier and at higher rates than women, according to a new study.
snippet: Men develop mild cognitive impairment, often a precursor to Alzheimer’s disease, earlier and at higher rates than women, according to a new study.
lead_paragraph: Men develop mild cognitive impairment, often a precursor to Alzheimer’s disease, earlier and at higher rates than women, according to a new study of almost 2,000 people in their 70s and 80s.

headline.print_headline: AGING: Men Face More Forgetting, and Earlier

abstract: Though recent evidence shows two types of tests can detect Alzheimer’s early, so far nothing has been found to prevent or delay the devastating disease.
snippet: Though recent evidence shows two types of tests can detect Alzheimer’s early, so far nothing has been found to prevent or delay the devastating disease.
lead_paragraph: BETHESDA, Md.  The scene was a kind of science court. On trial was the question “Can anything  running on a treadmill, eating more spinach, learning Arabic  prevent Alzheimer’s disease or delay its progression?”

abstract: The key to a collaborative Alzheimer’s project was an ambitious agreement to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately.
snippet: The key to a collaborative Alzheimer’s project was an ambitious agreement to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately.
lead_paragraph: In 2003, a group of scientists and executives from the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the drug and medical-imaging industries, universities and nonprofit groups joined in a project that experts say had no precedent: a collaborative effort to find the biological markers that show the progression of Alzheimer’s disease in the human brain.

abstract: Scientists are making steady gains toward developing highly useful tests that can predict whether patients are likely to develop Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Scientists are making steady gains toward developing highly useful tests that can predict whether patients are likely to develop Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Scientists are making steady gains toward developing tests that can predict whether patients with mild cognitive difficulties or even no symptoms at all are likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimer’s disease. The latest research, published this week in the Archives of Neurology, a journal of the American Medical Association, found that a test of spinal fluid performed exceptionally well in identifying patients with Alzheimer’s or on the way to developing it.

abstract: Groups that have proposed new diagnostic guidelines seek to counter criticism that drug companies will be the main beneficiaries.
snippet: Groups that have proposed new diagnostic guidelines seek to counter criticism that drug companies will be the main beneficiaries.
lead_paragraph: Will Alzheimer’s disease, a terrible degenerative brain disease with no treatments and no clear guidelines for diagnosis before its end stages, become like heart disease? That might mean early markers of risk, analogous to high cholesterol levels, that predict who is likely to get it. And it might mean drugs that actually prevent it.

abstract: A new type of Alzheimer’s  drug study will, in the boldest effort yet, test the leading hypothesis about how to slow or stop this terrifying brain disease.
snippet: A new type of Alzheimer’s  drug study will, in the boldest effort yet, test the leading hypothesis about how to slow or stop this terrifying brain disease.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Maldonado is not quite sure why she is at the Memory Enhancement Center in the seaside town of Oakhurst, N.J.

lead_paragraph: A small company with a new brain scan for detecting plaque, the hallmark physical sign of Alzheimer’s disease, presented its results on Sunday at an international conference in Hawaii, and experts who attended said the data persuaded them that the method works.

abstract: In the latest Patient Voices segment, producer Karen Barrow explores the frightening and confusing world of Alzheimer’s.
snippet: In the latest Patient Voices segment, producer Karen Barrow explores the frightening and confusing world of Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: In the latest Patient Voices segment, producer Karen Barrow explores the frightening and confusing world of Alzheimer’s. She captures the voices of both patients and loved ones who are struggling with issues of independence, long-term care and making the most of the time they have left.
headline.main: The Voices of Alzheimer’s

abstract: Researchers may have found a way to more accurately diagnose Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Researchers may have found a way to more accurately diagnose Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Researchers may have discovered a way to definitively diagnose Alzheimer’s disease in living patients, The Times reports today. If the findings hold up, scientists may have a way to figure out whether drugs are slowing or halting the disease, a step that “will change everyone’s thinking about Alzheimer’s in a dramatic way,” said one expert.
headline.main: Diagnosing Alzheimer’s

abstract: Readers respond to an article about new tests to detect Alzheimer’s.
snippet: Readers respond to an article about new tests to detect Alzheimer’s.

headline.print_headline: Our Alzheimer’s Risk: Better to Know?

abstract: A “buddy program” at the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern unites researchers and people with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: A “buddy program” at the Feinberg School of Medicine at Northwestern unites researchers and people with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: When Richard Kluzak, a retired real estate developer in Naperville, traveled to London last spring with his wife to visit their daughter, the festive quickly morphed into the frustrating. The father, 72, did not recognize his daughter, 43.
headline.main: Giving Researchers a Face for Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: Giving Researchers A Face for Alzheimer’s

abstract: How far has a family member with Alzheimer’s declined? A new online tool tries to help users figure it out.
snippet: How far has a family member with Alzheimer’s declined? A new online tool tries to help users figure it out.
lead_paragraph: Many Web sites offer help for stressed caregivers in general and information on Alzheimer’s disease in particular (the Alzheimer’s Association site is particularly comprehensive). But they don’t fully harness the Web’s interactivity to provide specific, tailored advice regarding Alzheimer’s — recommendations that necessarily change as patients’ behaviors and symptoms shift.
headline.main: Plotting the Course of Alzheimer’s

abstract: The drug, called Dimebon, failed in its first late-stage clinical trial, dealing a blow to patients with Alzheimer’s and the companies developing the treatment, Medivation and Pfizer.
snippet: The drug, called Dimebon, failed in its first late-stage clinical trial, dealing a blow to patients with Alzheimer’s and the companies developing the treatment, Medivation and Pfizer.
lead_paragraph: It seemed somewhat unlikely, but in recent years an old Russian hay fever pill had become one of the world’s best hopes for treating the growing epidemic of Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: Hopes for Alzheimer’s Drug Are Dashed
headline.print_headline: As an Alzheimer’s Drug Fails, Hopes Fall

abstract: One of the first signs of impending dementia: an inability to understand money and contracts.
snippet: One of the first signs of impending dementia: an inability to understand money and contracts.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning on the difficult questions raised for lawyers, doctors and financial advisers when a client begins to show signs of dementia.
headline.main: Personal Finances and Alzheimer’s

abstract: A expert at Duke has authored an unusually informative guide for caregivers and the elderly facing Alzheimer’s.
snippet: A expert at Duke has authored an unusually informative guide for caregivers and the elderly facing Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: It’s been nearly 30 years since Dr. Peter Rabins, a Johns Hopkins psychiatrist, and his co-author Nancy Mace published “The 36-Hour Day,” the best known guide to caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease. Now in its fourth edition, it remains a trusted source of information and support.
headline.main: The Caregiver’s Bookshelf: The Beginnings of Alzheimer’s

abstract: Medical experts are proposing major changes in the way Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed.
snippet: Medical experts are proposing major changes in the way Alzheimer’s disease is diagnosed.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in more than two decades, medical experts are proposing a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier.
headline.main: New Ways to Diagnose Alzheimer’s

snippet: One family is at the center of potentially groundbreaking research to see if treatment before dementia can stop Alzheimer’s.
lead_paragraph: YARUMAL, Colombia — Tucked away on a steep street in this rough-hewn mountain town, an old woman found herself diapering her middle-age children.

abstract: The National Institute on Aging has published an excellent new guide on caring for those with Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: The National Institute on Aging has published an excellent new guide on caring for those with Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: What I like about the new guide for those caring for people with Alzheimer’s disease, published by the National Institute on Aging, is that it’s:a) simply written;b) comprehensive, covering issues from medical conditions and legal documents to why you shouldn’t try to take your relative’s temperature with a glass thermometer;c) free.
headline.main: Caregiving and Alzheimer’s: A Road Map

abstract: A new guide to caring for those with Alzheimer’s does not shy away from difficult and sensitive issues.
snippet: A new guide to caring for those with Alzheimer’s does not shy away from difficult and sensitive issues.
lead_paragraph: The National Institute on Aging’s new guide for those caring for someone with Alzheimer’s disease, which I recommended a few weeks ago, drew generally positive reviews from New Old Age readers.
headline.main: Answers for Tough Questions About Alzheimer’s

abstract: Researchers are trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate. If drugs can be given sooner, they say, treatment might be more successful.
snippet: Researchers are trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate. If drugs can be given sooner, they say, treatment might be more successful.
lead_paragraph: Much of the research on Alzheimer’s next year will be about going back in time, trying to determine when and how the brain begins to deteriorate.

abstract: While most Alzheimer’s research focuses on blocking amyloid and plaque, other scientists are concentrating on another protein, tau.
snippet: While most Alzheimer’s research focuses on blocking amyloid and plaque, other scientists are concentrating on another protein, tau.
lead_paragraph: Ideas about how to treat Alzheimer’s fall into two main categories. The main one pins its hopes on blocking amyloid beta peptides that form areas of plaque on the brain. But there is also another protein, tau, that is part of the disease. Tau is damaged when patients have Alzheimer’s, chemically modified so it wrecks structures inside cells that are used to transport chemicals.

abstract: The drug maker stops another late-stage clinical trial, representing yet another failure in efforts to treat the disease.
snippet: The drug maker stops another late-stage clinical trial, representing yet another failure in efforts to treat the disease.
lead_paragraph: In yet another setback in efforts to treat Alzheimer’s disease, Eli Lilly & Company announced on Tuesday that it had halted development of an experimental treatment after the compound actually made patients worse in two late-stage clinical trials.
headline.main: Lilly Halts Alzheimer’s Drug Trial

abstract: Beta amyloid, which was once thought to be a chief villain in Alzheimer’s, may be part of the brain’s normal defenses, researchers at Harvard suggested.
snippet: Beta amyloid, which was once thought to be a chief villain in Alzheimer’s, may be part of the brain’s normal defenses, researchers at Harvard suggested.
lead_paragraph: For years, a prevailing theory has been that one of the chief villains in Alzheimer’s disease has no real function other than as a waste product that the brain never properly disposed of.

headline.print_headline: Infection Defense May Spur Alzheimer’s

abstract: A study showed that people who mostly ate foods low in saturated fat and rich in nutrients were at one-third lower risk of the disease than those who ate more higher-fat foods.
snippet: A study showed that people who mostly ate foods low in saturated fat and rich in nutrients were at one-third lower risk of the disease than those who ate more higher-fat foods.
lead_paragraph: Older adults appear to be at lower risk for Alzheimer’s disease if they eat a diet rich in fish, poultry, fruit, nuts, dark leafy greens, vegetables like broccoli and cauliflower, and oil-and-vinegar dressing, a new study has found.
headline.main: Aging: Diet May Be Linked to Lower Alzheimer’s Risk in Older People
headline.print_headline: AGING: Diet Is Linked to a Lower Alzheimer’s Risk

abstract: Should patients be given an early diagnosis of Alzheimer’s if there’s nothing they can do about it? And why are the diagnostic guidelines changing, anyway?
snippet: Should patients be given an early diagnosis of Alzheimer’s if there’s nothing they can do about it? And why are the diagnostic guidelines changing, anyway?
lead_paragraph: In July, medical experts proposed a major change in the criteria for Alzheimer’s disease, part of a new movement to diagnose and, eventually, treat the disease earlier. The new diagnostic guidelines would mean that new technology like brain scans would be used to detect the disease even before there are evident memory problems or other symptoms.
headline.main: Who Benefits From Early Diagnosis of Alzheimer’s?

abstract: Responses to an article about the effects of Alzheimer’s disease on the ability to understand money.
snippet: Responses to an article about the effects of Alzheimer’s disease on the ability to understand money.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
headline.main: Assessing Alzheimer’s
headline.print_headline: Assessing Alzheimer’s

abstract: New cooperation among Alzheimer’s researchers is beginning to pay off.
snippet: New cooperation among Alzheimer’s researchers is beginning to pay off.
lead_paragraph: The Times reports this morning that a shift in research strategy among scientists is beginning to yield insights into how Alzheimer’s disease begins. The key to the Alzheimer’s project was an agreement as ambitious as its goal: not just to raise money, not just to do research on a vast scale, but also to share all the data, making every single finding public immediately, available to anyone with a computer anywhere in the world.
headline.main: A Scientific Shift Yields New Insights Into Alzheimer’s

abstract: Tuesday, there was a match between elder French and Russian chess players that was part of a study to see if engaging in rigorous mental activity can prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
snippet: Tuesday, there was a match between elder French and Russian chess players that was part of a study to see if engaging in rigorous mental activity can prevent Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Chess can be diverting, amusing, engrossing, perplexing, exasperating, infuriating, and a few other things. But is it good for your mental health?
headline.main: Can Playing Chess Prevent Alzheimer’s Disease?

abstract: Even in the later stages of dementia, many Alzheimer’s patients enjoy and benefit from books, experts have found.
snippet: Even in the later stages of dementia, many Alzheimer’s patients enjoy and benefit from books, experts have found.
lead_paragraph: Familiar music can engage those with Alzheimer’s when almost nothing else can, researchers have shown. Now it appears that books written for these patients may have a similar effect.
headline.main: Many Alzheimer’s Patients Find Comfort in Books

abstract: Dr. Butler was a psychiatrist whose painful youthful realization that death is inevitable prompted him to challenge and ultimately reform the treatment of the elderly through research.
snippet: Dr. Butler was a psychiatrist whose painful youthful realization that death is inevitable prompted him to challenge and ultimately reform the treatment of the elderly through research.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert N. Butler, a psychiatrist whose painful youthful realization that death is inevitable prompted him to challenge and ultimately reform the treatment of the elderly through research, public policy and a Pulitzer Prize-winning book, died Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83 and had worked until three days before his death.

abstract: The patients agreed to be scanned for Alzheimer plaque before they died and then have their brains examined after death to see if a company’s new system worked.
snippet: The patients agreed to be scanned for Alzheimer plaque before they died and then have their brains examined after death to see if a company’s new system worked.
lead_paragraph: About 11 a.m. on May 19, Dr. Thomas Beach, a pathologist at Banner Sun Health Research Institute in Sun City, Ariz., stood in front of a long metal table, wearing gloves and an apron, and held up the brain of Patient 36 in an Avid Radiopharmaceuticals study.

abstract: For those in a Colombian clan, the anguish of Alzheimer’s may be hardest on those who do not have the disease, but know they are likely to get it.
snippet: For those in a Colombian clan, the anguish of Alzheimer’s may be hardest on those who do not have the disease, but know they are likely to get it.
lead_paragraph: The anguish of Alzheimer’s in a sprawling extended family in Colombia may be hardest on those still lucid enough to know they have it, or those who know they could.
headline.main: A Family’s Torment as Relatives Slip Away
headline.print_headline: Fear Grips a Family as Relatives Slip Away

abstract: In 1982, Dr. Francisco Lopera, a Medellín neurologist, was puzzled by a 47-year-old patient who was losing his memory and other cases that followed. Dr. Lopera burned to help.
snippet: In 1982, Dr. Francisco Lopera, a Medellín neurologist, was puzzled by a 47-year-old patient who was losing his memory and other cases that followed. Dr. Lopera burned to help.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, Dr. Francisco Lopera, a Medellín neurologist, was puzzled. A 47-year-old patient was losing his memory, and so had his father, grandfather and seven other relatives.

abstract: Search-and-rescue officials are facing a growing number of people with Alzheimer’s disease or other forms of dementia who wander from home.

lead_paragraph: ASHBURN, Va. — For generations, the prototypical search-and-rescue case in America was Timmy in the well, with Lassie barking insistently to summon help. Lost children and adolescents — from the woods to the mall — generally outnumbered all others.

abstract: A front-page article about a promising new study of Alzheimer’s carried a subhead that said “100% Accuracy Found in Study Results” and a lead paragraph that seemed to support the claim. The piece drew dissenting comments from a number of readers.
snippet: A front-page article about a promising new study of Alzheimer’s carried a subhead that said “100% Accuracy Found in Study Results” and a lead paragraph that seemed to support the claim. The piece drew dissenting comments from a number of readers.
lead_paragraph: The new public editor’s blog opens with an entry in the field of science, something my mama told me never to do.
headline.main: The Trouble With Absolutes

abstract: Solutions to wandering can be as simple as a sign on the door and as complex as personal GPS monitors.
snippet: Solutions to wandering can be as simple as a sign on the door and as complex as personal GPS monitors.
lead_paragraph: One Alzheimer’s wanderer in Arizona had lost much of his memory, but not, apparently, his interest in fashion: he never left the house without a beloved baseball cap on his head. So a trick the family used to keep the man around was to hide his caps.
headline.main: Resources and Technology to Help Caregivers Cope
headline.print_headline: Resources and Technology To Help Caregivers Cope

abstract: By studying an extended family in Colombia where Alzheimer’s is seen in the early 40s, scientists hope to find a treatment for Alzheimer’s patients worldwide.
snippet: By studying an extended family in Colombia where Alzheimer’s is seen in the early 40s, scientists hope to find a treatment for Alzheimer’s patients worldwide.
lead_paragraph: By studying an extended family in Colombia where Alzheimer’s is seen in the early 40s, scientists hope to find a treatment for Alzheimer’s patients worldwide.
headline.main: The Vanishing Mind

abstract: Robert B. Schaefer, a retired F.B.I. agent, answers questions from readers about how to help dementia patients prone to wandering.
snippet: Robert B. Schaefer, a retired F.B.I. agent, answers questions from readers about how to help dementia patients prone to wandering.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent Kirk Johnson reports in Tuesday’s Times that frequent searches for people with dementia or Alzheimer’s disease are fueling a need to retrain emergency workers, police and volunteers around the country. They must throw out just about every generally accepted idea when hunting for people who are, in many ways, lost from the inside out.
headline.main: Readers’ Questions: Dementia and Wandering

abstract: Writers remember the people in their lives with Alzheimer’s, and the result is a potent, poignant book.
snippet: Writers remember the people in their lives with Alzheimer’s, and the result is a potent, poignant book.
lead_paragraph: Nearly nine years ago, the poet and essayist Holly J. Hughes’s 75-year-old mother died from Alzheimer’s disease. Her mother’s decline had been “a slow process of subtraction, as we lost her one brain cell, one synapse at a time,” Ms. Hughes writes in the preface to a new collection of poetry about this rampaging disease. “As with any grief that feels unspeakable, I turned to poetry.”
headline.main: Poets of Dementia

snippet: How can society deal with the coming flood of Alzheimer’s patients?
lead_paragraph: Updated, June 3, 1:05 p.m. | Marc E. Agronin, a geriatric psychiatrist, joins the discussion, pointing out the significant challenges to treating dementia patients.
headline.main: When Boomers Get Dementia

abstract: Researchers have tested the Sensecam, which contains a digital camera and an accelerometer, as an aid to people with Alzheimer’s disease and other memory disorders.
snippet: Researchers have tested the Sensecam, which contains a digital camera and an accelerometer, as an aid to people with Alzheimer’s disease and other memory disorders.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — On a cold, wet afternoon not long ago, Aron Reznick sat in the lounge of a home for the elderly here, his silver hair neatly combed, his memory a fog. He could not remember Thanksgiving dinner with his family, though when he was given a hint — “turkey” — it came back to him, vaguely, like a shadow in the moonlight.

abstract: The Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Thursday that the playwright and director Alan Ayckbourn and the Tony Award-winning actress Marian Seldes had been chosen to receive Lifetime Achievement Awards. Mr. Ayckbourn, who has written more than 70 plays, is probably best known for the “The Norman Conquests,” which won the Tony Award for best revival of a play in 2009. Ms. Seldes, who made her Broadway debut in “Medea” in 1947, won as featured actress for “A Delicate Balance” in 1967. Another familiar face on Broadway, David Hyde Pierce, above, is being given the Isabelle Stevenson Award, which recognizes charitable and humanitarian work. He is being honored for his contributions toward finding a cure for Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: The Tony Awards Administration Committee announced on Thursday that the playwright and director Alan Ayckbourn and the Tony Award-winning actress Marian Seldes had been chosen to receive Lifetime Achievement Awards. Mr. Ayckbourn, who has written more than 70 plays, is probably best known for the “The Norman Conquests,” which won the Tony Award for best revival of a play in 2009. Ms. Seldes, who made her Broadway debut in “Medea” in 1947, won as featured actress for “A Delicate Balance” in 1967. Another familiar face on Broadway, David Hyde Pierce, above, is being given the Isabelle Stevenson Award, which recognizes charitable and humanitarian work. He is being honored for his contributions toward finding a cure for Alzheimer’s disease.
headline.main: Ayckbourn and Seldes Are Early Tony Winners
headline.print_headline: Ayckbourn And Seldes Are Early Tony Winners

abstract: Pressure is growing on the drug giant facing generic competition.
snippet: Pressure is growing on the drug giant facing generic competition.
lead_paragraph: After Tuesday’s double dose of bad news for Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical company bought a full-page advertisement in The Indianapolis Star on Wednesday to reassure its hometown supporters of a brighter future.
headline.main: Lilly Tries to Reassure Hometown

abstract: the legendary Hollywood beauty
snippet: the legendary Hollywood beauty
lead_paragraph: Rita Hayworth, the legendary Hollywood beauty who rose to international fame in the 1940's and 1950's, died Thursday night, of Alzheimer's disease, in her Central Park West apartment in Manhattan. She was 68 years old.
headline.main: Rita Hayworth, Movie Legend, Dies

abstract: The company will seek to develop nutritional products for diseases like diabetes, obesity, cardiovascular disease and Alzheimer’s.

abstract: In “Lil’s 90th,” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, a look at how dementia can devastate even the most loving family.
snippet: In “Lil’s 90th,” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, a look at how dementia can devastate even the most loving family.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, love is not all you need. In fact, it can be downright dangerous. Love abounds in the family depicted in Darci Picoult’s new play, “Lil’s 90th”; but the Eldridges are in big, big trouble anyway.

abstract: A jazz singer grapples with her mother’s memory loss.
snippet: A jazz singer grapples with her mother’s memory loss.
lead_paragraph: Cynthia Scott’s voice came wafting out of my car radio on a Sunday morning. She’s a lovely singer, a veteran of jazz clubs and international festivals and, back when, one of Ray Charles’s Raelettes.
headline.main: A Song About Forgetting

abstract: Sleep apnea can mimic or exacerbate symptoms of cognitive decline in the elderly.
snippet: Sleep apnea can mimic or exacerbate symptoms of cognitive decline in the elderly.
lead_paragraph: The woman who came to see Dr. Ronald Petersen, an Alzheimer’s specialist at the Mayo Clinic, was only in her 60s but complained that she was having trouble concentrating. “Her attention was waning,” Dr. Petersen recalled. “She couldn’t follow a television program or stay focused during a conversation.”
headline.main: When Sleep Apnea Masquerades as Dementia

abstract: September 20 | Updated – Last month I commented here on the problems that arise when a story or headline couches some development as an absolute – in this case, new research describing a relationship between certain proteins and Alzheimer’s disease. In the Aug. 10 article by Gina Kolata, a subhead promised “100% Accuracy Found in Study Results.”

abstract: James P. King has won the Amazon award.
snippet: James P. King has won the Amazon award.
lead_paragraph: With the publication this week of his first novel, “Bill Warrington’s Last Chance,” James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer’s disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. “This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do,” the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King’s fourth attempt at fiction.
headline.main: Breakthrough Award for New Novelist

abstract: Steven M. Volpe, a recent college graduate and an avid computer user, turned his interest in social media into a job for the Alzheimer’s Association.
snippet: Steven M. Volpe, a recent college graduate and an avid computer user, turned his interest in social media into a job for the Alzheimer’s Association.
lead_paragraph: Steven M. Volpe, 21, who graduated in June from the College of Staten Island, parlayed an unpaid spring internship at the New York City chapter of the Alzheimer’s Association into a paid summer internship. In August he was offered a job as a social media associate. He lives with his parents in Dongan Hills on Staten Island and moonlights Saturday nights selling business machines at a local Staples.

abstract: Premieres of new plays by Neil LaBute, Michael Weller and Sharr White (“Six Years”) will make up the 2010-11 season of MCC Theater.
snippet: Premieres of new plays by Neil LaBute, Michael Weller and Sharr White (“Six Years”) will make up the 2010-11 season of MCC Theater.
lead_paragraph: Premieres of new plays by Neil LaBute, Michael Weller and Sharr White (“Six Years”) will make up the 2010-11 season of MCC Theater, that Off Broadway theater company said. According to a preview of MCC’s season, which will run at the Lucille Lortel Theater, Mr. LaBute’s new play, “The Break of Noon,” about a spiritual awakening after an office shooting, will be directed by his frequent collaborator Jo Bonney. The show will be a co-production with the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles. Mr. White will make his New York debut with “The Other Place,” about a strong-headed Alzheimer’s researcher whose private life takes a scary turn. Mr. Weller’s new play, “Side Effects,” is a sequel of sorts to his last MCC show, “Fifty Words,” which turned in part on the revelation of an extramarital affair.
headline.main: LaBute and Weller in MCC’s New Season

abstract: Joe Girardi, expected to be a top candidate for the vacant Cubs manager position, addressed concerns that he would leave the Yankees.
snippet: Joe Girardi, expected to be a top candidate for the vacant Cubs manager position, addressed concerns that he would leave the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO  Waiting in Joe Girardi’s office Friday was a copy of The Chicago Sun-Times, which on its back page featured a silhouette of a man wearing a Cubs hat. Beneath a list of nine qualities the next Cubs manager must have, it read, “There’s only one man for the job.” On Page 56, there was a large photograph of Girardi. He did not get that far.

abstract: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon.”
snippet: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon.”
lead_paragraph: Amanda Peet will join David Duchovny in MCC Theater’s production of Neil LaBute’s “Break of Noon,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Duchovny was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty playing that man’s wife, Ginger, and Ginger’s cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12. MCC Theater’s second production of the 2010-11 season will pair Laurie Metcalf (“Roseanne,” “Brighton Beach Memoirs”) with her “November” director, Joe Mantello for the world premiere of Sharr White’s “Other Place.” In this thriller, Ms. Metcalf will play a woman who finds herself at the center of a mystery just as she hits upon a potential breakthrough in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It is to begin at the Lortel on March 10 and open on March 28, with a limited run through April 24. ... Mos Def, Jeffrey Wright and Paul Dano are among the cast members in Lincoln Center Theater’s coming production of John Guare’s play “A Free Man of Color,” the theater announced on Monday. Mr. Guare’s drama, set in New Orleans in the early 19th century, will be directed by George C. Wolfe. Previews begin on Oct. 21, with opening night set for Nov. 18 at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.
headline.main: Theater News
headline.print_headline: Theater News

abstract: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”
snippet: As members of the baby boom generation begin to turn 65, they may need to re-examine the notion that “age is just a number.”
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY turned 65, just ahead of the millions in the baby boom generation who will begin to cross the same symbolically fraught threshold in the new year to a chorus of well-intended assurances that “age is just a number.” But my family album tells a different story. I am descended from a long line of women who lived into their 90s, and their last years suggest that my generation’s vision of an ageless old age bears about as much resemblance to real old age as our earlier idealization of painless childbirth without drugs did to real labor.
headline.main: Real Life Among the Old Old
headline.print_headline: Real Life Among the Old Old

abstract: Those middle-aged smokers who use two packs a day have twice the risk, according to a study of 23,123 health plan members.
snippet: Those middle-aged smokers who use two packs a day have twice the risk, according to a study of 23,123 health plan members.
lead_paragraph: Middle-aged smokers are far more likely than nonsmokers to develop dementia later in life, and heavy smokers  those who go through more than two packs a day  are at more than double the risk, a new study reports.
headline.main: Risks: Smokers Found More Prone to Dementia
headline.print_headline: RISKS: Smokers Found More Prone to Dementia

abstract: Ms. Peet will star with David Duchovny in Neil LaBute’s “The Break of Noon,” and Ms. Metcalf will star in Sharr White’s “The Other Place,” to be directed by Joe Mantello.
snippet: Ms. Peet will star with David Duchovny in Neil LaBute’s “The Break of Noon,” and Ms. Metcalf will star in Sharr White’s “The Other Place,” to be directed by Joe Mantello.
lead_paragraph: It may not be Mulder and Scully back together, but an “X-Files” reunion of sorts will be coming to the New York stage this fall. MCC Theater said on Monday that Amanda Peet, the star of  films like “Please Give” and “The Whole Nine Yards,” will be re-teamed with David Duchovny in its production of Neil LaBute‘s “Break of Noon.” (As all dedicated X-philes know, Ms. Peet previously appeared opposite Mr. Duchovny in the 2008 film “The X-Files: I Want to Believe” and shares some scathing tongue-in-cheek thoughts on him in the film’s making-of documentary.) Mr. Duchonvy was previously slated to play a man who sees the face of God during an office shooting; Ms. Peet will do double duty as that man’s wife, Ginger, and Ginger’s cousin, Jesse. The play, to be directed by Jo Bonney, will begin previews at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Oct. 28 and open on Nov. 15; its limited run is scheduled through Dec. 12.
headline.main: Amanda Peet and Laurie Metcalf Join MCC Theater Productions

lead_paragraph: Charlie Popovich is a former linebacker for two National Football League teams who still loves to hit, even at age 54. Charlie, who is immensely likable, has Alzheimer’s disease, the central fact of “Pop.”

abstract: Decoding the genome has led to stunning advances in scientific knowledge but has done relatively little to improve medical treatments or human health.

lead_paragraph: On June 26, 2000, two scientific teams announced at the White House that they had deciphered virtually the entire human genome, a prodigious feat that involved determining the exact sequence of chemical units in human genetic material. An enthusiastic President Clinton predicted a revolution in “the diagnosis, prevention and treatment of most, if not all, human diseases.”

abstract: To get tenure, scientists ordinarily have to demonstrate that they have an impressive record of published research. Dr. Bishop failed that test, scientists said.
snippet: To get tenure, scientists ordinarily have to demonstrate that they have an impressive record of published research. Dr. Bishop failed that test, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Neurobiologists say Amy Bishop did not actually have an exciting new idea for treating degenerative nervous system diseases like multiple sclerosis or Alzheimer’s. And her invention of a better petri dish did not seem like something that is needed or wanted in research laboratories.

abstract: Answers become parts of clues in this web of cross-connections.
snippet: Answers become parts of clues in this web of cross-connections.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Mike Nothnagel is known for his very tough Friday and Saturday puzzles, but today he proves he can do a simpler Thursday-style crossword as well. As Thursdays go, this one isn’t as wild and crazy as some, but it’s clever and interesting, and the way everything cross-connects can make your head spin. If you’re not careful, you can get a false sense of déjà vu when clues that seem to be familiar turn out to be different.
headline.main: Cross-Connections

abstract: Lawmakers need to look at what is happening beyond the Beltway. While they refuse to provide more fiscal aid to states, their constituents are suffering.
snippet: Lawmakers need to look at what is happening beyond the Beltway. While they refuse to provide more fiscal aid to states, their constituents are suffering.
lead_paragraph: How bad does it have to get before Congress notices? Kevin Sack reported in The Times on Thursday that budget shortfalls have led 11 states to close enrollment in programs that provide drugs to people with H.I.V. and AIDS. Worse, the number of those turned away is expected to surge in the months ahead as more states defer enrollment and cut eligibility.

abstract: The practitioners of snowboarding’s increasingly complex and risky tricks have begun to consider potential problems looming later in life.
snippet: The practitioners of snowboarding’s increasingly complex and risky tricks have begun to consider potential problems looming later in life.
lead_paragraph: STRATTON, Vt. — One of the uglier crashes of Scotty Lago’s snowboarding career occurred last summer during a halfpipe competition in New Zealand. While attempting a Cab 1080 — a spin of three rotations — Lago struck his upper body hard on the lip of the halfpipe, sending his hat (he was not wearing a helmet) and goggles flying. He fell 20 feet to the bottom of the pipe, striking the back of his head, and tumbling to a stop.

abstract: With the future stability of the show in severe doubt, Tuesday’s premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. What did you think of the episode?
snippet: With the future stability of the show in severe doubt, Tuesday’s premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. What did you think of the episode?
lead_paragraph: Let the long period of national mourning begin: the ninth season of “American Idol” began tonight, and it was two hours of dead-man-walking. With the future stability of the show in doubt, Tuesday’s premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. Soak in Simon Cowell‘s evident distaste for Kara Dioguardi; ponder the physics of Victoria Beckham‘s head tilt; let the shock of a contestant saying Randy Jackson’s his favorite judge sting anew. Soon, this will all be just a memory.
headline.main: Down by the Banks of the River Charles: The ‘American Idol’ Premiere

abstract: “I wondered whether human music had been shaped for our brains by evolution — meaning, it helped us survive.”
snippet: “I wondered whether human music had been shaped for our brains by evolution — meaning, it helped us survive.”
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when Oxford University Press published “Music, Language, and the Brain,” Oliver Sacks described it as “a major synthesis that will be indispensable to neuroscientists.” The author of that volume, Aniruddh D. Patel, a 44-year-old senior fellow at the Neurosciences Institute in San Diego, was in New York City in May. We spoke over coffee for more than an hour and later by telephone. An edited and condensed version of the conversations follows.

abstract: Student Opinion | What quirky rituals or “lucky” objects help you prepare for important events?

lead_paragraph: With the New York City Marathon just two days away, runners have been revealing some of the superstitions and rituals that they believe will affect how well they will run those famous 26.2 miles. What superstitions do you follow, and why?

abstract: In this first novel, a widowed research scientist tries to solve the puzzle of his marriage.
snippet: In this first novel, a widowed research scientist tries to solve the puzzle of his marriage.
lead_paragraph: In fiction as in life, you can’t save people from themselves. Although that never keeps anyone from trying, as Rosecrans Baldwin’s amiable first novel demonstrates. Dr. Victor Aaron is 58 years old, a research scientist specializing in Alzheimer’s disease at a small (but well endowed) college on Mount Desert Island in Maine. Almost three years earlier, he lost his wife, Sara, in a car accident. They had no children. Everyone around Victor is concerned about him, and with good reason. His response to Sara’s death is not so much stoic as anesthetized. He goes about his routines of healthy breakfast, swimming, work and more work, seeming increasingly numb and remote. As another character puts it, “Your wife had died and everyone knew but you.”

abstract: The disease was called “shaking palsy” before it took the name of James Parkinson.
snippet: The disease was called “shaking palsy” before it took the name of James Parkinson.
lead_paragraph: Parkinson’s disease is second only to Alzheimer’s as the most common neurological illness in the United States, and its symptoms  rigidity, imbalance and uncontrollable shaking  are all too familiar. By the time James Parkinson formally described it in 1817, the illness had been known for centuries.

abstract: “Harvest,” written and directed by Marc Meyers, will be shown May 9 at the Connecticut Film Festival in Danbury.
snippet: “Harvest,” written and directed by Marc Meyers, will be shown May 9 at the Connecticut Film Festival in Danbury.
lead_paragraph: “EVERYTHING your grandfather does this summer will be for the last time,” says Anna in Marc Meyers’s film “Harvest.” Anna (the Tony Award winner Victoria Clark) is trying to persuade her college-age son, Josh (Jack Carpenter), to stay at the family house in Madison for the whole summer, not just for the weekend. But that argument could be difficult to make, because Robert Loggia, as Anna’s father, Siv, looks so robust, so engaged and enthusiastic that you would swear he could put off any funeral planning until at least 2030.

abstract: The characters in Sue Miller’s new novel are connected by a theatrical production.
snippet: The characters in Sue Miller’s new novel are connected by a theatrical production.
lead_paragraph: Early on in Sue Miller’s new novel, “The Lake Shore Limited,” a ­middle-aged woman loiters in a dark street, peeping into the window of a bar. Inside, a much younger woman — vivid in a crimson suit, flanked by men, “her long legs on display” — throws her head back to laugh, “either in pure pleasure or in the wish to convey pure pleasure.” The moment is quintessential Miller, touching on the themes that have animated her fiction for the past quarter-century: the potency of sex; the failure of men and women to understand each other; the hunger for a different life. Here too is the hyper-self-consciousness that afflicts her characters, who are forever questioning the authenticity of their feelings.

abstract: Mr. Mann helped persuade Republicans and fellow Southern Democrats to line up behind the impeachment of a president.
snippet: Mr. Mann helped persuade Republicans and fellow Southern Democrats to line up behind the impeachment of a president.
lead_paragraph: James R. Mann, a South Carolina congressman who played a critical role in drafting the articles of impeachment against Richard M. Nixon and emerged as one of the South’s most eloquent voices on the matter, died Monday in Greenville, S.C. He was 90.

abstract: Yvonne Fernandez said that after she yelled at Judi DeMarco, they hugged, cried and made up.
snippet: Yvonne Fernandez said that after she yelled at Judi DeMarco, they hugged, cried and made up.
lead_paragraph: After she screamed at a fellow juror in the trial of Brooke Astor’s son, Yvonne Fernandez said, she and the other woman made up, hugged and cried together in the bathroom. Even after the trial, Ms. Fernandez added, that fellow juror, Judi DeMarco, left her a pleasant voice-mail message.

abstract: Ms. Tuttle, an innovator in technique for her instrument, was praised by critics for her incisive musicianship and large, luminous sound.
snippet: Ms. Tuttle, an innovator in technique for her instrument, was praised by critics for her incisive musicianship and large, luminous sound.
lead_paragraph: Karen Tuttle, a violist and teacher whose singular approach to her instrument  which entailed the expression of deep feeling, the attainment of great physical comfort and occasionally the literal rending of garments  drew disciples from around the world, died on Dec. 16 at her home in Philadelphia. She was 90.

abstract: New guidelines on driving and dementia are less definitive than many caregivers might have hoped for.
snippet: New guidelines on driving and dementia are less definitive than many caregivers might have hoped for.
lead_paragraph: You might hope that when the American Academy of Neurology reviews and updates its decade-old guidelines on driving and dementia, the experts would come up with clear-cut recommendations: a specific score on a specific test means someone can head for the mall without much concern, or a  particular behavior means it’s too risky to be on the road, so hand over the keys.
headline.main: Driving While Demented

abstract: Often we imagine that life ends at the nursing home door, a myopic view that hurts the aging as well as ourselves.
snippet: Often we imagine that life ends at the nursing home door, a myopic view that hurts the aging as well as ourselves.
lead_paragraph: The old woman had drawn down the shade in her room  hoping, I imagined, to stop the midday Miami sun from penetrating her grief. But the sun still hit the window full force and illuminated the shade like a Chinese lantern.

abstract: Marathoners are known for some quirky superstitions, from wearing green underwear, to eating matzah to requesting the same number. If it works, don’t ask them why.
snippet: Marathoners are known for some quirky superstitions, from wearing green underwear, to eating matzah to requesting the same number. If it works, don’t ask them why.
lead_paragraph: When the cannons go off on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Sunday, Mary Darling will savor an instant of peace before the adrenaline charges through her. She knows that her best friend’s father has just lit a candle — timed precisely for her start of the New York City Marathon — at St. Christopher’s Church in Baldwin, N.Y., just as he does for every marathon she runs.
headline.main: Spaghetti, the No. 8 and Green Underwear: Rituals to Run With

abstract: A new book explores the developing science on how long, and how well, humans can live.
snippet: A new book explores the developing science on how long, and how well, humans can live.
lead_paragraph: My theory is that the more intensely involved we are with caring for the very old and sick, the less appealing the notion of ever-longer lifespans becomes.
headline.main: When I’m 164

abstract: Several states have enacted bans. Others have outlined specific limits on consumption or possession. But is this all worth the trouble?
snippet: Several states have enacted bans. Others have outlined specific limits on consumption or possession. But is this all worth the trouble?
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL weeks after Miley Cyrus turned 18 in November, a video surfaced showing the pop singer and actor celebrating her adulthood with uncontrollable laughter, garbled speech and a shapely bong. It was neither marijuana nor hashish in the pipe, she explained in the face of public furor, but Salvia divinorum, a powerful hallucinogenic that adults can legally use in California.

abstract: The Greek-born artist used colors of nature, some inspired by his beloved tree peonies, in precise geometric forms.
snippet: The Greek-born artist used colors of nature, some inspired by his beloved tree peonies, in precise geometric forms.
lead_paragraph: Nassos Daphnis, a Greek-American artist who deployed brilliantly colored geometric forms in precise formal relationships to create nervous, dynamic paintings on a heroic scale, died on Nov. 23 in Provincetown, Mass. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

abstract: Older couples can receive more thorough care when they see a doctor together.
snippet: Older couples can receive more thorough care when they see a doctor together.
lead_paragraph: Their doctor calls Carrie and Tulane Howard “the ‘Rear Window’ couple.” They spend hours sitting by the bay window, in the house they bought in Northwest Washington, D.C., in 1951, looking out at their garden and beyond it to Rock Creek Park.
headline.main: Better Together

abstract: A holdout juror’s claim that threats caused her to cave in and convict Brooke Astor’s son of fraud was exaggerated and inaccurate, prosecutors argued.
snippet: A holdout juror’s claim that threats caused her to cave in and convict Brooke Astor’s son of fraud was exaggerated and inaccurate, prosecutors argued.
lead_paragraph: A holdout juror’s claim that another juror’s threats caused her to cave in and convict Brooke Astor’s son of fraud was exaggerated and inaccurate, Manhattan prosecutors argued in a brief filed on Friday.
headline.main: Manhattan Prosecutors Dispute Juror’s Account in Astor Trial
headline.print_headline: Manhattan Prosecutors Dispute Juror’s Account in Astor Trial

abstract: Lesson Plan | Examining the nature of scientific advancement and recent developments in science, and considering what types of discoveries merit inclusion in textbooks.
snippet: Lesson Plan | Examining the nature of scientific advancement and recent developments in science, and considering what types of discoveries merit inclusion in textbooks.
lead_paragraph: Overview  | How are discoveries and breakthroughs made in science? What kinds of scientific developments merit inclusion in course textbooks? In this lesson, students consider the nature of scientific research and explore recent and anticipated advancements in science. They then create digital supplements to update their own science textbooks.
headline.main: What’s Next: Updating Science Textbooks With New Discoveries
byline.original: By Jennifer Cutraro and Holly Epstein Ojalvo

abstract: New science is showing that estrogen’s effects on women’s minds and bodies may depend upon when they first start taking it. What should you do?
snippet: New science is showing that estrogen’s effects on women’s minds and bodies may depend upon when they first start taking it. What should you do?
lead_paragraph: Here we are, two fast-talking women on estrogen, staring at a wall of live mitochondria from the brain of a rat. Mitochondria are cellular energy generators of unfathomably tiny size, but these are vivid and big because they were hit with dye in a petri dish and enlarged for projection purposes. They’re winking and zooming, like shooting stars. “Oh, my God,” Roberta Diaz Brinton said. “Look at that one. I love these. I love shooting mitochondria.”

abstract: Ms. Leachman, the “Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “Young Frankenstein” star, talks about her new Fox sitcom and laughs. A lot.
snippet: Ms. Leachman, the “Mary Tyler Moore Show” and “Young Frankenstein” star, talks about her new Fox sitcom and laughs. A lot.
lead_paragraph: “Raising Hope,” a new comedy that makes its debut Tuesday night on Fox, is a very funny show: in a review for The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley wrote that the series, about a family “so eccentrically cemented to their way of life and to one another that soon anything else seems alien and unappealing,” could be “the best new sitcom of the season.”
headline.main: Cloris Leachman Finds ‘Raising Hope’ Really, Really, Really Funny. (Really.)

abstract: A professor at the University of California, Berkeley, for nearly four decades, he traveled the world and helped found the Pacific News Service.
snippet: A professor at the University of California, Berkeley, for nearly four decades, he traveled the world and helped found the Pacific News Service.
lead_paragraph: Franz Schurmann, an expert on China during the cold war and a globe-trotting professor who helped found the Pacific News Service, a provider of news and commentary about Asia, died on Aug. 20 at his home in San Francisco. He was 84. The cause was complications of Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s diseases, his wife, Sandy Close, said.

abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
snippet: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBINE,  by Dave Cullen (Twelve, $15.99.) Everything you think you know about the Columbine High School massacre of April 20, 1999, is wrong. The shooters, Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold, were not victims of bullying. They did not belong to a goth “Trench Coat Mafia.” They did not single out blacks or Christians or athletes. “Eric Harris was a psychopath, simple as that,” our reviewer, Jennifer Senior, reported. “Dylan Klebold was a suicidally depressed kid who yoked his fate to a sadist.” This book by Cullen, who as a reporter in Denver covered the story for Salon and Slate, is a “fine example of old-fashioned journalism,” Senior said.

abstract: Mr. Webber’s initiatives included remaking a major New York seminary, starting storefront churches in Harlem and beginning a program to educate prison inmates as pastors.
snippet: Mr. Webber’s initiatives included remaking a major New York seminary, starting storefront churches in Harlem and beginning a program to educate prison inmates as pastors.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. George W. Webber, a Protestant minister and educator whose quest to make religion more socially relevant led him to remake a major seminary, start storefront churches in East Harlem and begin a program to educate prison inmates as pastors, died Saturday at his home in Maplewood, N.J. He was 90.

abstract: Mr. Suarez, a Cuban refugee, rose to become president of the Miami Herald and the founder and publisher of the newspaper’s independent Spanish-language sister, El Nuevo Herald.
snippet: Mr. Suarez, a Cuban refugee, rose to become president of the Miami Herald and the founder and publisher of the newspaper’s independent Spanish-language sister, El Nuevo Herald.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Suarez, a Cuban refugee whose career in journalism started late  in the mailroom of The Miami Herald  but who rose to become president of the company and the founder and publisher of the newspaper’s independent Spanish-language sister, El Nuevo Herald, died Wednesday at his home in Miami. He was 82.

abstract: Surprising research turns up at forum sponsored by the National Transportation Safety Board.

lead_paragraph: “There are a lot of different pieces to this puzzle,” said Deborah Hersman, chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board, which last week sponsored a two-day forum called “Safety, Mobility and Aging Drivers.”

abstract: Ms. Boulding, an instructor at Dartmouth and the University of Colorado, was also an author of numerous books.
snippet: Ms. Boulding, an instructor at Dartmouth and the University of Colorado, was also an author of numerous books.
lead_paragraph: Elise Boulding, a sociologist, pacifist feminist and scholar who wrote extensively about conflict resolution in both personal and global relations and who helped establish the academic field known as peace studies, died June 24 in Needham, Mass. She was 89.

abstract: Mr. Donner was part of the British New Wave filmmakers with “The Caretaker” and “What’s New Pussycat?”
snippet: Mr. Donner was part of the British New Wave filmmakers with “The Caretaker” and “What’s New Pussycat?”
lead_paragraph: Clive Donner, who helped define the British New Wave with films like “The Caretaker” and “Nothing but the Best” and directed the emblematic swinging ’60s film “What’s New Pussycat?,” died on Tuesday in London. He was 84.

abstract: A culture obsessed with youth is undergoing a subtle and, for performers and the public alike, increasingly welcome shift.
snippet: A culture obsessed with youth is undergoing a subtle and, for performers and the public alike, increasingly welcome shift.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese culture is renowned for its obsession with the impermanence of beauty, and many a poem has honored the brief but perfect life of the cherry blossom.
headline.main: As Japan Ages, Pop 'Idols' Aren't as Spry as They Used to Be
headline.print_headline: As Japan Ages, Pop 'Idols' Aren't as Spry as They Used to Be

abstract: Copiapó was known at a darker moment in Chile’s history as the site of a murder of 16 people by an army delegation.
snippet: Copiapó was known at a darker moment in Chile’s history as the site of a murder of 16 people by an army delegation.
lead_paragraph: COPIAPÓ, Chile — Though the vuvuzelas have quieted down, this desert city is still basking in the daring rescue of the 33 men trapped deep in a copper and gold mine nearby for more than two months. And for some, the triumph was a striking contrast to another set of events here in Copiapó — also involving its miners — from a much darker time in Chile’s history.

abstract: Mr. Callahan was a quadriplegic, alcoholic cartoonist who was known for drawings that made impolitic sport of people with disabilities and diseases.
snippet: Mr. Callahan was a quadriplegic, alcoholic cartoonist who was known for drawings that made impolitic sport of people with disabilities and diseases.
lead_paragraph: John Callahan, a quadriplegic, alcoholic cartoonist whose work in newspapers and magazines made irreverent, impolitic sport of people with disabilities and diseases and those who would pity and condescend to them, died on Saturday in Portland, Ore. He was 59 and lived in Portland.

abstract: Adultery. Children never born. Degrees achieved but not useful. Failed marriages. Readers share their regrets.
snippet: Adultery. Children never born. Degrees achieved but not useful. Failed marriages. Readers share their regrets.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, Christine Haughney of City Room asked readers to tell us about any financial decisions of recent years that they would like to undo. We received so many comments that we ran a bunch in a post. But then that post generated a whole new set of comments. This time, for reasons unclear to us, readers expanded their regrets beyond the financial sphere — in many cases far, far beyond it. We now give you a selection, lightly edited. Warning: You may have nightmares. It is a coincidence that we are running this on the day after an election.
headline.main: You Will Regret Reading This

abstract: Families that speak freely about estate planning can sometimes address awkward situations and avoid unwelcome surprises.
snippet: Families that speak freely about estate planning can sometimes address awkward situations and avoid unwelcome surprises.
lead_paragraph: FOR many people, estate planning is both a private matter and a morbid topic — not something that parents and their adult children want to discuss. While having these conversations takes a lot of courage, they can help avoid surprises, lead to better financial planning and promote family harmony.

abstract: Every patient has a story; how good it is depends on your own experience.
snippet: Every patient has a story; how good it is depends on your own experience.
lead_paragraph: “A poet,” James Dickey once said, “is someone who stands outside in the rain hoping to be struck by lightning.” But what about the obvious follow-up question, regarding people who happen to be out in the rain and happen to be struck by lightning? Should each of them then become a poet  or perhaps the author of a slim volume of nonfiction?

lead_paragraph: “What should you do if your parent is drawing close to dying but doesn’t want to talk about it?” I asked.
headline.main: Talking About Dying

abstract: Beneath the titillating promos of “Sunset Daze,” there is a more reassuring portrait of adults who can still act like kids but are at peace with their twilight years.
snippet: Beneath the titillating promos of “Sunset Daze,” there is a more reassuring portrait of adults who can still act like kids but are at peace with their twilight years.
lead_paragraph: It’s not true that there are no old people on television, but they mostly stand out in ads that veer between extremes. The elderly are either vernally lithe, active and amorous (Cialis) or feeble home-care patients dependent on emergency alert systems and Exelon, an Alzheimer’s patch, to stave off undignified and agonizing deaths.

abstract: New York State played a big role in the Civil War but the state is not interested in any commemoration.
snippet: New York State played a big role in the Civil War but the state is not interested in any commemoration.
lead_paragraph: It was anything but civil. On Jan. 7, 1861, Mayor Fernando Wood exhorted New York’s Board of Aldermen to declare the city’s independence from Albany and from Washington — a bold stroke of self-preservation that he maintained “would have the whole and united support of the Southern States.”

abstract: Mr. Silber, a founder of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, was one of the prime movers behind the folk-music revival of the 1950s and 1960s.
snippet: Mr. Silber, a founder of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, was one of the prime movers behind the folk-music revival of the 1950s and 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Irwin Silber, a founder and the longtime editor of the folk-music magazine Sing Out!, who was one of the prime movers behind the folk-music revival of the 1950s and 1960s and, on a famous occasion, treated Bob Dylan to a public scolding for abandoning his political songs, died on Wednesday in Oakland, Calif. He was 84.

abstract: In “The Memory Show,” the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.
snippet: In “The Memory Show,” the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.
lead_paragraph: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — “The Memory Show,” which recently opened at Barrington Stage Company here, is a musical in search of a melody. That is what it intends to be. In shaping a portrait of a mother with Alzheimer’s disease and the angry, impotent daughter who cares for her, the young composer Zach Redler has written a score that follows the patterns of minds grasping, often in vain, for clarity, conviction and lost time.

abstract: The Children’s Aid Society helped Desiree and Robert Whitlow to pay bills while they were jobless and to enroll their daughter with the Dance Theater of Harlem.

abstract: A photographer searches for memories of her mother in one of the most reliable places possible: her closet.
snippet: A photographer searches for memories of her mother in one of the most reliable places possible: her closet.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t take a mountain of fashion magazines or even a slim volume of Roland Barthes to understand that a mere outfit can be profound. Just look back at your wardrobe over time. (Thanks, Facebook, for making this painfully easier.) The prom dress in which you lost your virginity, the hideous interview suit for the job you never got — clothes become shorthand for experiences, and powerful triggers of memories. The universality of “I dress, therefore I am” is what propelled Ilene Beckman’s 1995 memoir, “Love, Loss and What I Wore,” to the best-seller list, and then to a Broadway play by Nora and Delia Ephron. Now comes the photographer Jeannette Montgomery Barron’s series of photographs and written recollections, “My Mother’s Clothes.” A group of still lifes depicting the wardrobe of her late mother, the prominent Atlanta socialite Eleanor Morgan Montgomery Atuk, “My Mother’s Clothes” will be on display in July at Jackson Fine Art in Atlanta and published as a book in March 2010.
headline.main: Dress to Regress | A Photographer’s Fashion Flashbacks

abstract: When the archaeologist first saw the crumbling Yemeni structure, Dr. Radi said, “Wow, this we’ve got to save.”
snippet: When the archaeologist first saw the crumbling Yemeni structure, Dr. Radi said, “Wow, this we’ve got to save.”
lead_paragraph: On certain dark nights, as a Yemeni legend tells it, Sultan Amir ibn Abd Al-Wahhab would command his servants to set lanterns in the windows of the Amiriya Madrasa, the ornate palace complex he had commissioned at Rada, in southern Yemen. Then, with his daughter by his side, he would ride into the hills above town, to behold his vast edifice ablaze with light.

abstract: Two plays — “Really Old, Like Forty Five” and a revival of Chekhov’s “Three Sisters” — have mixed success in relaying prickly problems of everyday life.
snippet: Two plays — “Really Old, Like Forty Five” and a revival of Chekhov’s “Three Sisters” — have mixed success in relaying prickly problems of everyday life.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — What’s in a name? Pretty much everything when it comes to “Really Old, Like Forty Five,” the Tamsin Oglesby play that has opened at the National’s Cottesloe Theatre, where it runs in repertory through April 20. Ms. Oglesby’s title is intriguing and funny, even prickly, depending where in your life you happen to be. (These days, 45 seems quite young to me.) But the play attached to it seems like a statistic-laden screed that never comes into focus. Savor the playwright’s gift for naming, but give the show a miss.

abstract: Visiting the south of France as part of a well-oiled campaign to promote “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” Michael Douglas effortlessly plays the part of matinee idol.
snippet: Visiting the south of France as part of a well-oiled campaign to promote “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” Michael Douglas effortlessly plays the part of matinee idol.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — My 10 minutes with Michael Douglas ran precisely 13:58. That, at least, is the time on my recorder, though the hovering, smiling, apologetic if insistent publicist tried to cut it short. Mr. Douglas and I shared our 13 long minutes together on Thursday afternoon on the roof of the Palais Stéphanie, a hôtel de luxe facing the Mediterranean that was recently spiffed up with striped carpeting and a giant palm frond – as in Palme d’Or, the highest prize at the Cannes Film Festival – which juts up like an obelisk in the yawning lobby. We were there to discuss his return to his most famous character, Gordon Gekko, the Wall Street don who made us feel so good about greed. “Everybody,” Mr. Douglas said with a laugh, “likes a bad guy.”
headline.main: A Star (Charmingly) Sells the Goods at Cannes

abstract: It’s a challenge for Priscilla Leontitsis, a musician, to care for her husband, Nicolas, who has multiple sclerosis, but she said: “I’m 77. I’m able to work.”
snippet: It’s a challenge for Priscilla Leontitsis, a musician, to care for her husband, Nicolas, who has multiple sclerosis, but she said: “I’m 77. I’m able to work.”
lead_paragraph: Priscilla Leontitsis first spotted her future husband, Nicolas, in 1989 at Oasis, a Greek restaurant in White Plains that he owned. She was a local choir director and soprano, and she had stopped in for dinner.

abstract: It now appears possible to sequence a patient’s genome at reasonable cost and with sufficient accuracy to be useful.
snippet: It now appears possible to sequence a patient’s genome at reasonable cost and with sufficient accuracy to be useful.
lead_paragraph: Two research teams have independently decoded the entire genome of patients to find the exact genetic cause of their diseases. The approach may offer a new start in the so far disappointing effort to identify the genetic roots of major killers like heart disease, diabetes and Alzheimer’s.

abstract: After trying for 10 years, Robert Lantos has finally succeeded in making a film of “Barney’s Version,” his friend Mordecai Richler’s last novel.
snippet: After trying for 10 years, Robert Lantos has finally succeeded in making a film of “Barney’s Version,” his friend Mordecai Richler’s last novel.
lead_paragraph: IN this country Mordecai Richler is probably best known for the movie “The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz,” based on his novel of the same name. (With Lionel Chetwynd, he also wrote the screenplay.) But for some unaccountable reason Richler, who died in 2001, was immensely popular in Italy, where was last novel, “Barney’s Version,”was a best seller. And in his native Canada he was a national institution, cherished because of the way he indiscriminately poked fun at Canadians in general, but especially the Jews, the French separatists and the Anglophile nationalists, who were locked in mutual antagonism.

abstract: The New York Film Festival presents the movies it believes to be this year’s essential viewing, through Oct. 10.
snippet: The New York Film Festival presents the movies it believes to be this year’s essential viewing, through Oct. 10.
lead_paragraph: The New York Film Festival  which begins its 48th iteration Friday night at Lincoln Center with a gala screening of “The Social Network”  is at once buoyed and burdened by its past. This is true of other festivals, too. Spend a few hours at Sundance or Cannes and you are bound to hear someone conjuring up the old days, when indie film really, you know, mattered or when Marcello Mastroianniwas standing right over there.

abstract: Though the goal is to live long and live well, only a minority of Americans incorporate into their lives what will give them the biggest bang for their buck: diet and exercise.
snippet: Though the goal is to live long and live well, only a minority of Americans incorporate into their lives what will give them the biggest bang for their buck: diet and exercise.
lead_paragraph: The Great Recession, so I’m told, has been great for one segment of the economy  the makers of pills and potions that offer the promise of keeping people healthy. A middle-aged woman remarked as she perused the supplement shelves in my local health food store (I was buying bulgur): “I can’t afford to get sick. I lost my job and I have no health insurance.”

abstract: With little fanfare, Congress approved wide-ranging plans to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.
snippet: With little fanfare, Congress approved wide-ranging plans to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amid all the rancor leading up to passage of the new health care law, Congress with little fanfare approved a set of wide-ranging public initiatives to prevent disease and encourage healthy behavior.

abstract: Ms. Kreps was President Jimmy Carter’s Secretary of Commerce, the first woman to hold a post traditionally occupied by men with business interests.
snippet: Ms. Kreps was President Jimmy Carter’s Secretary of Commerce, the first woman to hold a post traditionally occupied by men with business interests.
lead_paragraph: Juanita M. Kreps, who was President Jimmy Carter’s secretary of commerce from 1977 to 1979, the first woman and the first economist to hold a post traditionally occupied by men with business interests, died Monday in Durham, N.C. She was 89.

abstract: Known for his integration of modernist design and sophisticated engineering in buildings, Mr. Graham played a role in changing Chicago’s skyline.
snippet: Known for his integration of modernist design and sophisticated engineering in buildings, Mr. Graham played a role in changing Chicago’s skyline.
lead_paragraph: Bruce J. Graham, whose integration of modernist design and sophisticated engineering in buildings like the John Hancock Center and the Sears Tower transformed the skyline of Chicago and reasserted the city’s pre-eminence as a world architectural capital, died on Saturday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla. He was 84.

abstract: Decisions about aggressive treatment at the end of life are far from clear-cut.
snippet: Decisions about aggressive treatment at the end of life are far from clear-cut.
lead_paragraph: Aggressive treatment at the end of life  frantic CPR for a brain-dead accident victim, inserting a feeding tube in a dying Alzheimer’s patient  has become a staple of the health care debate. Critics argue that vast resources are squandered on care that is obviously futile.

abstract: New York’s hate-crime statute requires proof only that defendants committed a crime because of a belief they held about the group, not that they hate the group.
snippet: New York’s hate-crime statute requires proof only that defendants committed a crime because of a belief they held about the group, not that they hate the group.
lead_paragraph: In the public’s imagination, the classic hate crime is an assault born of animus against a particular ethnicity or sexual orientation, like the case of the Long Island man convicted in April of killing an Ecuadorean immigrant after hunting for Hispanics to beat up.

abstract: The Society for American Baseball Research changed course and recognized Dorothy Jane Mills as a co-author with Dr. Harold Seymour of a trilogy of the game’s history.
snippet: The Society for American Baseball Research changed course and recognized Dorothy Jane Mills as a co-author with Dr. Harold Seymour of a trilogy of the game’s history.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Jane Mills was supposed to feel honored last Monday when the Society for American Baseball Research included her husband, Dr. Harold Seymour, in the inaugural class of the organization’s new de facto Hall of Fame. She was supposed to feel thankful that her assistance with Seymour’s seminal three-volume history of baseball, published sequentially from 1960 through 1990, would be acknowledged during his induction.
